background: a 64 years old female with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and fibromyalgia, who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent cardiac catheterization with stent placement in the RCA.
question: What are the best discharge instructions for a patient with a history of STEMI and stent placement?
A: You should continue to take aspirin for life. Take plavix for 6 months without skipping any doses. Stop plavix if feeling better. You should continue to take all your medications as prescribed.
B: You should continue to take aspirin for life. Take plavix for 12 months without skipping any doses. Do NOT stop plavix for any reason without speaking to your cardiologist first. You should continue to take all your medications as prescribed.
C: Take aspirin for 6 months. Take plavix for 12 months without skipping any doses. Do NOT stop plavix for any reason without speaking to your cardiologist first. Take medications only when symptomatic.
D: You should continue to take aspirin for 5 years. Take plavix for 12 months without skipping any doses. Do NOT stop plavix for any reason without speaking to your cardiologist first. You should continue to take all your medications as prescribed.
E: You should continue to take aspirin for life. Take clopidogrel for 3 months without skipping any doses. Do NOT stop plavix for any reason without speaking to your cardiologist first. You should continue to take all your medications as prescribed.

background: a patient who underwent a two-part lumbar spine surgery and is recovering well with stable vital signs and pain control
question: What are the best post-discharge activity recommendations for a patient recovering from lumbar spine surgery?
A: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around. Once a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.
B: You should not lift anything greater than 20 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than ~30 minutes without getting up and walking around. 2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.
C: Avoid bending at the waist for 2 weeks. Use a cane for support when walking. 2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.
D: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around. 2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.
E: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around. Engage in light stretching exercises as part of your recovery.

background: A patient underwent an ileostomy reversal with complications leading to an end colostomy. The patient had a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU and was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Pertinent lab results indicate anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels.
question: What are the best follow-up care recommendations for a patient post-ileostomy reversal with an end colostomy?
A: Monitor incision site. If you notice that you have not had any stool from your stoma in days, please call the office. If you do not see improvement and are having symptoms of fever (chills, sweating, or body aches) please call the office or go to the emergency room. If you notice that the stoma is turning darker blue or purple please call the office or go to the emergency room.
B: Monitor stoma output. If you notice that you have not had any stool from your stoma in days, please call the office. If you do not see improvement and are having symptoms of dehydration (headache, lightheadedness, dizziness, dark urine, or dry mouth) please call the office or go to the emergency room. If you notice that the stoma is turning darker blue or purple please call the office or go to the emergency room.
C: Monitor blood pressure. If you notice that you have not had any stool from your stoma in days, please call the office. If you do not see improvement and are having symptoms of nausea and vomiting please call the office or go to the emergency room. If you notice that the stoma is turning darker blue or purple please call the office or go to the emergency room.
D: Monitor stoma output. If you notice that you have not had any stool from your stoma in days, please call the office. If you do not see improvement and are having symptoms of dehydration (headache, lightheadedness, dizziness, dark urine, or dry mouth) please call the office or go to the emergency room. If you notice that you have a skin rash please call the office or go to the emergency room.
E: Monitor stoma output. If you notice that you have not had any stool from your stoma in days, please call the office. If you do not see improvement and are having symptoms of dehydration (headache, lightheadedness, dizziness, dark urine, or dry mouth) please call the office or go to the emergency room. If you notice that you have joint pain please call the office or go to the emergency room.

A: Apply antiseptic cream daily. Limit caffeine intake. Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.

Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.
D: You may shower and bathe normally. Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics. Take laxatives daily. Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.
E: You may shower and bathe normally. Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics. Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Start a new vitamin regimen.

background: a male patient with a history of coronary artery disease, admitted following a syncopal episode with profound vertigo, and diagnosed with carotid stenosis and mild-to-moderate degenerative changes of the cervical spine.

A: Please continue to take your home medications as directed. Please make sure you attend your follow up with your primary care doctor. D: Please continue to take your home medications as directed. Please make sure you attend your follow up with your primary care doctor. If you develop chest pain, please call your doctor or return to the emergency room. If you develop shortness of breath, please call your doctor or return to the emergency room. If you develop any concerning symptom, please call your doctor or return to the emergency room.

If you develop shortness of breath, please call your doctor or return to the emergency room. If you develop any concerning symptom, please call your doctor or return to the emergency room.

background: A 39-year-old female was admitted for a gynecological procedure, specifically an abdominal myomectomy following preoperative uterine artery embolization. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated, and she was discharged in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
question: What are the best discharge instructions for a patient recovering from an abdominal myomectomy?
A: Do not take more than 4000mg ibuprofen in 24 hrs. No light activity until your post-op appointment. Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks. No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
B: Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks. No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
C: Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. Avoid swimming for 4 weeks. No running for 3 weeks.
D: Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks. No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 4 weeks.
E: Limit caffeine intake. No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks. No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.

background: A gentleman admitted with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, diagnosed with a high-grade small-bowel obstruction. Underwent exploratory laparotomy and lysis of adhesions. Post-operative course was uneventful, and he is preparing for discharge with stable vital signs.

C: Please resume all regular home medications and take any new meds as ordered. Avoid standing for long periods. Begin light stretching exercises. You may shower, no tub baths or swimming.
D: Please resume all regular home medications and take any new meds as ordered. No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises. You may shower, no swimming.
E: Continue taking prescribed pain medications as needed. No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises. You may shower, no tub baths or swimming.

background: A 77-year-old male was admitted with fever and underwent ERCP for rising bilirubin levels, revealing sludge/small stones in the lower third of the common bile duct. A biliary stent was placed, and a percutaneous cholecystotomy was performed. The patient's diet was advanced to a regular low-fat diet, and liver function tests normalized. The patient expressed a desire to return home and was discharged with follow-up instructions.

C: Resume all home medications. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow-up appointment, at least. Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications. Call your surgeon to make a follow-up appointment.
D: Resume all home medications. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow-up appointment, at least. Driving is allowed while taking pain medications. Call your surgeon to make a follow-up appointment.
E: Resume all home medications. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow-up appointment, at least. Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications. No need for a follow-up appointment.

D: Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. You have been given medications for pain control. Please follow the pain medication instructions provided. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.
E: Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. Start new medications as prescribed. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.

background: an elderly female with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes, who underwent a left carotid endarterectomy and had an uneventful recovery.

background: A patient with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with symptoms of unstable angina, new T-wave inversions on EKG, and slight troponin elevation.

background: A patient with a right foot wound showing mixed bacterial infection, including gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci, with moderate growth of viridans streptococci.
question: What are the best discharge instructions for a patient with a mixed bacterial infection in the right foot?

B: Please keep your bandage clean, dry, and intact until your first follow-up appointment. Take Amoxicillin (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours for 10 days. Take Cipro (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth twice daily for 10 days. Please remain weight bearing in your surgical shoe with crutches.
C: Please keep your bandage clean, dry, and intact until your first follow-up appointment. Take Clindamycin (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours for 10 days. Take Cipro (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth twice daily for 10 days. Please remain non-weight bearing in your surgical shoe with crutches.
D: Please keep your bandage moist and covered until your first follow-up appointment. Take Clindamycin (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours for 10 days. Take Cipro (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth twice daily for 10 days. Please remain non-weight bearing in your surgical shoe with crutches.
E: Please keep your bandage clean, dry, and intact until your first follow-up appointment. Take Azithromycin (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours for 10 days. Take Cipro (antibiotic) 1 tablet by mouth twice daily for 10 days. Please remain non-weight bearing in your surgical shoe with crutches.

background: a patient admitted for planned ORIF of a left zygomatic fracture and underwent an uncomplicated ORIF.
question: What are the best discharge instructions for a patient who has undergone an uncomplicated ORIF of a left zygomatic fracture?
A: Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
B: Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. You may take over-the-counter pain medication for moderate to severe pain. You may switch to aspirin for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
C: Start a new vitamin regimen. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Take probiotics daily.
D: Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Take antibiotics only if you feel unwell.
E: Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to severe pain. Use herbal remedies for mild pain. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.

background: A female patient underwent a right thoracotomy, right upper lobectomy, and mediastinal lymph node dissection. background: a female patient who underwent ERCP and laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis and choledocholithiasis, with a stable postoperative course and discharge instructions focusing on incision care and activity resumption.
question: What are the best discharge instructions for a patient recovering from a laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
A: You may start moderate exercise when you feel comfortable. Avoid only swimming pools while your incision is healing. If feelings and reactions do not go away in a short time, tell your surgeon. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
B: You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools while your incision is healing. If feelings and reactions do not go away in a short time, tell your surgeon. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
C: You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools while your incision is healing. Report any mild discomfort to your surgeon. Remove steri-strips after 1 week.
D: You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools while your incision is healing. Report any symptoms to your surgeon. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.
E: You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools while your incision is healing. If feelings and reactions do not go away in a short time, tell your surgeon. Keep steri-strips for 1 week.
